title: 111_s591
content:
The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission for these purposes. The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel, known as the "Commission," is established to evaluate improvements in the US approach to waste management if the Yucca Mountain repository is not operational. The Commission will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for managing defense waste, spent nuclear fuel, high-level waste, and commercial radioactive waste. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders in consultation with relevant committees. Qualifications for members include not being nongovernmental appointees. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by different leaders. Qualifications include not being engaged in high-level radioactive waste activities or being a government employee. Members should be prominent US citizens with expertise in relevant fields. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by leaders, with qualifications including expertise in relevant fields. Members must not be involved in high-level radioactive waste activities or be government employees. The Chairperson is appointed under subsection (a)(5) and leads the Commission. Meetings are called by the Chairperson or majority members, with a quorum of five members required. Vacancies on the Commission are addressed promptly. After the initial meeting, the Commission will meet as called by the Chairperson or majority members. A quorum of five members is required for meetings. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's spent fuel and high-level waste strategies, including transferring responsibility to a Government corporation, providing funding for storage and management, cost-sharing with private industry for technology development, and establishing interim storage facilities in communities. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for nuclear fuel management, including cost-sharing with private industry, establishing interim storage facilities, and transferring title of spent nuclear fuel inventories to the Department of Energy. Advanced fuel cycle technologies are also being researched to address weapons proliferation concerns. The Act requires the transfer of spent nuclear fuel inventories to at-reactor dry casks for public safety and security. It also mandates permanent disposal of civilian and defense wastes in deep geologic repositories, along with interim strategies for defense waste treatment. Additionally, it includes measures for improved security of spent nuclear fuel storage installations. The Commission is tasked with recommending permanent disposal solutions for civilian and defense nuclear wastes, interim strategies for defense waste treatment, and additional management approaches. It will consult with various stakeholders, submit recommendations on fee disposition, and analyze the financial impacts of its recommendations. The Commission will submit recommendations on fee disposition and analyze the financial impacts of its recommendations on the Federal Government's contractual liability under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982. A final report containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations will be submitted to Congress. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, administer oaths, enter into contracts, and obtain information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out the duties under this Act. The Federal Government is required to provide information, suggestions, estimates, and statistics to the Commission as requested. Information must be handled and disseminated in accordance with applicable laws. The General Services Administration will offer administrative support to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission may receive administrative support from the General Services Administration and other federal agencies as needed. They are also allowed to use postal services like other government departments. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission, and they may receive administrative support from the General Services Administration and other federal agencies as needed. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint staff and set their compensation without following certain federal employment rules. The staff director and personnel are considered federal employees for specific purposes under title 5 of the United States Code. The Commission's staff director and personnel are federal employees under specific sections of title 5 of the United States Code. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, retaining their rights and privileges. The Commission can also procure consultant services at specified rates. SEC. 9. COMPENSATION; TRAVEL EXPENSES.

Each Commission member may receive compensation up to the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for a level IV position under section 5315 of title 5, United States Code. They are also entitled to travel expenses while performing Commission duties, following the same rules as intermittent Government service employees under section 5703(b) of title 5, United States Code.

SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES. SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES. The Federal agencies shall cooperate with the Commission to provide appropriate security clearances to members and staff. No access to classified information without proper clearances. SEC. 11. REPORTS. The Commission must release an interim report within 1 year and a final report within 2 years. The final report should include agreed-upon findings, opinions of dissenting members, and consider public comments. SEC. 12. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds necessary for implementing the Act are authorized. SEC. 13. TERMINATION. SEC. 12. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary are authorized to carry out the Act, remaining available until expended. SEC. 13. TERMINATION. The Commission's authority ends 180 days after the final report submission, allowing for conclusion of activities and dissemination of the final report.
